title: Timeouts & Clock Management
subtitle: How Teams Control Time to Win Games

What you'll learn: How the game clock works and when it stops

script.hook: In football, time is everything. Master the clock, and you control the game. Let's learn how teams manipulate time to their advantage.

sections.title: Two Clocks Running
sections.content: Football has two clocks: the game clock (60 minutes of play) and the play clock (40 seconds to start each play). The game clock stops for incomplete passes, out of bounds, and timeouts. Otherwise, it keeps ticking.
sections.onScreen: dual clock display: game clock vs play clock with examples

sections.title: Each Team's Three Timeouts
sections.content: Teams get three timeouts per half - use them or lose them. Timeouts stop the clock for strategic planning, rest players, or save precious seconds in close games. They're like pause buttons you can only press three times.
sections.onScreen: timeout indicators depleting + '3 per half' visual

sections.title: Clock Stoppage Rules
sections.content: The clock stops for: incomplete passes, running out of bounds, scoring plays, and penalties. In the last 2 minutes of each half, the clock also stops briefly on first downs to move the chains.

sections.title: Two-Minute Warning
sections.content: At exactly 2:00 left in each half, play automatically stops - it's like a free timeout for both teams. This is when games get intense. Teams switch to hurry-up offense, spike balls to stop the clock, and use timeouts strategically.
sections.onScreen: 2:00 timer + 'TWO-MINUTE WARNING' alert + strategy shift visual

sections.title: Clock Strategy Examples
sections.content: Leading teams run the ball to keep the clock moving and burn opponent timeouts. Trailing teams pass more (stops clock on incompletions), use sidelines, and save timeouts for their final drive. It's chess with seconds.
sections.onScreen: split strategy: 'Leading: run clock' vs 'Trailing: save clock'

sections.title: Quick Recap
sections.content: Two clocks control the game. Three timeouts per half are precious. Clock stops on incompletions and out of bounds. Master these rules to understand late-game drama.

questions.question: How many timeouts does each team get per half?
questions.explanation: Each team gets 3 timeouts per half. Once you use them, they're gone until halftime. Then you get 3 more for the second half.

questions.question: What is the 'two-minute warning'?
options: A penalty for delay of game
An automatic stoppage at 2:00 left in each half
When teams must make a decision
A timeout called by the coach
questions.explanation: The two-minute warning is an automatic stoppage of play when exactly 2:00 remains in each half. It acts like a free timeout for both teams to strategize.

questions.question: When does the game clock stop running?
options: Only at the end of quarters
After incomplete passes, out of bounds, timeouts, and scores
questions.explanation: The clock stops for incomplete passes, when a player goes out of bounds, timeouts, penalties, scores, and injuries. This is why a 60-minute game takes 3+ hours!

questions.question: Your team is losing by 3 points with 1:30 left. You have 2 timeouts and the ball at midfield. What's your clock strategy?
options: Run the ball to control possession
Use both timeouts immediately to plan
Pass to the sidelines and save timeouts for defense
Let the clock run down before scoring
questions.explanation: Pass to the sidelines! Incompletions and receivers going out of bounds stop the clock naturally. Save those precious timeouts in case you need to stop the clock on a running play or if the defense needs them later.
